author: ralexstokes
content: a rollup operator will likely have all of their own chain state (including the L2 blocks) locally

author: ralexstokes
content: if there are several operators and there aren't more efficient ways to get the data then yes you can find nodes on that shard's subnet and sync the latest from them

author: ralexstokes
content: i expect blobs to be available for at least as long as the extent of the proof-of-custody game

author: ralexstokes
content: which is on the order of weeks, not days

author: ralexstokes
content: not even just validating nodes, even *full* nodes will want to also take part in the DAS

author: ralexstokes
content: so one thing i would like to see in the first consensus fork after the Merge is the addition of an opcode to provide the latest beacon state root `BEACONSTATEROOT` or something like this

author: ralexstokes
content: from there a rollup contract at L1 can verify some L2 block (as calldata) via some state root -> shard header root -> shard data inclusion proof

author: ralexstokes
content: no worries, you are asking all the right questions! there is certainly still some design space to explore here to figure out how to best fit all the moving parts together

author: yblue19
content:
Hi folks. I'm new to Eth. I have a question about sharding. I read through this and a few things are not that clear to me. https://ethereum.org/en/eth2/shard-chains/ Let's assume we are talking about the "State execution not needed" case for simplicity. 1) what's the sharding "key"? do we automatically shard transactions by transaction_hash? from address? to address? or entirely manual? 2) can a transaction be executed cross multiple shards? 

Just by reading the document it feels to me like manual: let's say agree arbitrum on shard 1, optimism on shard 2, dydx on shard 3.. and cross shards are not supported. is that right?
